fields.Title: Northern Goshawk (Accipiter gentilis) Breeding Status and Prey Relationships within the Cassia Section of the Minidoka Ranger District of the Sawtooth National Forest: 2012 Final Report
fields.Description/Abstract:
During the breeding seasons of 2011 and 2012, we systematically monitored the population of Northern
Goshawks residing in the Cassia Section, Minidoka Ranger District, of the Sawtooth National Forest (a.k.a. the
South Hills). We surveyed historical and potentially
new nesting areas for occupancy and monitored discovered
nests to gauge productivity. We installed nest cameras in
six nests to quantify the local diet of goshawks in the
natural absence of tree squirrels. We performed prey and habitat surveys to relate territory occupancy to forest
structure, health, and relative prey abundance. At a study
-wide scale we produced a habitat suitability model to
predict nesting locations to aid in future surveys and management decisions.
Territory occupancy was average
in 2011 (42%) and above average in
2012 (70%). Nest productivity
compared favorably to past studies in the south hills
and in other areas, ranging from 1.7 fledglings per
occupied nest in 2011 to 2.4 in 2012.
Occupancy rates and the low number of
sub-adult female breeders (one
per year) indicate this
population is healthy.
We found the breeding season diet to be dominated
by mammals and specifically the Belding’s Ground
Squirrel. In 2011, avian abundance was shown to influence territory occupancy, but no effect was discovered in
2012. None of our measures (nest stand, territory, or
prey availability) were shown to influence productivity.
We believe that these results are misleading. We believe
that occupancy was high in both years, but more nests
failed in 2011 before we gained access to discover them. With the late snow pack in 2011, avian abundance
influenced nest survival instead of nest occupancy.
In 2012 with the early emergence of ground squirrels, avian
abundance became less influential.
Our habitat suitability model illustrates that nests
of goshawks were more often associated with lower
elevations within the study area, with gentle or no slope, eastern facing aspect, in non-rugged terrain, with dense
canopy cover, and low relative reflectance in the green spectrum (0.53 – 0.61 ?m wavelength).
We recommend that forest management within the
area protect existing nest stands from excessive
disturbance, manage stands for multiple seral stages
of growth through thinning and encouragement of stand
regeneration, and manage to maintain prey abundances including robins, woodpeckers, grouse, and ground
squirrels.
